docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Get for Windows Get for Linux All Releases

docs.title: Original Project By DotBow
docs.text: The Blender Laucnher V2 project exists because DotBow/Blender-Launcher has been inactive since October of 2022. It was archived on the 28th of Nov, 2023 and will no longer be receiving updates.

docs.title: What is it?
docs.text:
Blender Launcher is a standalone software client that provides management for stable, daily and experimental builds of Blender 3D. It is a free open source project available for 64-bit Windows and Linux (GLIBC 2.27 and higher) operating systems.

Screenshots

Library Tab, Stable Page Downloads Tab, Daily Page User Tab, Favorites Page Tray Icon

docs.title: Why do I need it?
docs.text: The goal of Blender Launcher is to make it easier to stay up to date with the latest features and improvements of Blender 3D together with the security of stable releases. Being a minimalistic portable application it is a nice tool for organizing the evolving free and open source 3D creation suite.

docs.title: What features does it have?
docs.text:
Compared to its predecessor Blender Launcher introduces a number of major improvements:

  • Rewritten from the ground up for better stability and extensibility
  • All official builds are available:
    • Stable releases
    • Daily builds
    • Experimental branches
  • Faster starting times by caching data
  • Support for high DPI displays

Core features:

  • Automatic checking of latest builds
  • Fast access of favorite build via tray context menu or by middle click on tray icon
  • Register .blend file extension for preferred build
  • Startup arguments for launching Blender
  • Template installation
  • Indication of running builds and its number of instances

docs.title: How to start using it?
docs.text:
• Download latest version from releases page
  • Follow Installation instructions and notes
  • Use Blender Artists Community thread to ask questions and make proposals

docs.title: How to thank the developer?
docs.text:
• The best reward is feedback and a happy user face!

Thanx for using Blender Launcher! Have a good day!

docs.title: Build Initialization
docs.text:
Screenshots

Custom Build Library

Build initialization is used to set all the Blender Build information on the first installation of a Custom Build.

docs.title: Initialization Options
docs.text:
Screenshots

Initialization Options

docs.title: Executable Name
docs.text:
Enter the name of the executable for the custom Blender version.

Info

This supports auto-completion and will show you the existing available executable files as you type.

Warning

Make sure to input the correct executable name and do not select the BlenderLauncher.exe file.

docs.title: Auto Detect Information
docs.text: If the executable file has been found, the Auto Detect Option will be available. You can click on it to autofill all the build info fields.

docs.title: Subversion
docs.text: Subversion corresponds to the Blender version you are initializing. Example format: 4.0.2

docs.title: Build Hash
docs.text: Unique build ID.

docs.title: Commit Time
docs.text: Time when the build was created.

docs.title: Branch Name
docs.text: Name of the branch used to make the build.

docs.title: Custom Name
docs.text:
Name the build will have in the Blender Launcher.

Info

You can set any desired name here.

docs.title: Favorite
docs.text: Add the build to the Favorite builds in the Blender Launcher.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Linux or Windows x64
  • Python 3.9
  • pdm

Warning

To use different Python version, run pdm use to select the correct python interpreter

docs.title: Using Pdm
docs.text:
Note

All actions should be performed under repository root folder i.e. /Blender-Launcher-V2!

docs.title: Preparing virtual environment
docs.text:
1. Install pdm package

    pip install pdm

  2. Create the virtual environment

    python -m pip install virtualenv
python -m virtualenv --clear --download .venv
python -m ensurepip
python -m pip install --upgrade pdm
# Enter the virtual Environment
pdm venv activate
# ^ Execute the command this returns with!

  3. Install dependencies

    Minimum set of packages for building executable 
    pip install -e .
    All set of packages including development tools 
    pdm install

docs.title: Running Blender Launcher
docs.text:
Info

As of (c90f33d), cached Blender-Launcher-V2 files (such as resources_rc.py and global.qss) are no longer included in the source due to them artificially inflating git diffs. In order to generate them, run the build_style.py script located in the root project directory. running Blender Launcher without these being built will result in an error.

python source/main.py

docs.title: Building Blender Launcher .exe
docs.text:
Warning

Executables made in Pyinstaller must be built inside the target platform! You cannot build for a different platform other than your own.

Windows

  1. Run batch file

    .\build_win.bat

  2. Look for bundled app under Blender-Launcher-V2\dist\release folder

Linux

  1. Run shell script file

    sh build_linux.sh

  2. Look for bundled app under Blender-Launcher-V2/dist/release folder

docs.title: Preview the Documentation
docs.text:
Windows
  1. Run the batch file 
    .\script\mkdocs_serve.bat
  2. Open the Documentation in a web browser.
Linux
  1. Run the shell script file 
    sh .\script\mkdocs_serve.sh
  2. Open the Documentation in a web browser.

docs.title: Update the Documentation
docs.text:
Note

You should never edit the documentation in the gh-pages branch; this branch is used to publish the documentation.

Make the desired modifications in the .md files.

docs.title: Publish the Documentation
docs.text:
Windows
  1. Run the batch file 
    .\script\mkdocs_publish.bat
Linux
  1. Run the shell script file 
    sh .\script\mkdocs_publish.sh

docs.title: How to request a feature
docs.text:
Blender Launcher is relatively new project, so it is always nice to hear feedback and requests from Blender community about how to improve user experience. The best place to discuss proposals is a Blender Artists Community thread or Discord, however an issue template for feature request is also available.

Request a feature

docs.title: Installing Blender Launcher
docs.text:
1. Download latest release for your OS from releases page
  2. Unpack Blender Launcher.exe file and place it somewhere on your drive
  3. Run Blender Launcher.exe file
  4. If this is a first launch, program will ask for choosing Library Folder
  5. Enjoy!

docs.title: For Archlinux Users
docs.text: Install from AUR blender-launcher-bin or blender-launcher-git for experimental features

docs.title: Manual update
docs.text:
1. Download latest release for your OS from releases page
  2. Quit running instance of Blender Launcher
  3. Unpack Blender Launcher.exe file and replace existing one
  4. Enjoy!

docs.title: Automatic update
docs.text:
v1.15.1 and lower

Automatic updates are not available if you are using a version of the blender launcher prior to the 1.15.2 version. To update, you need to do a manual update of the blender launcher.

  1. Press the Update to version %.%.% button on the right bottom corner
  2. Wait until downloading and extracting process is finished
  3. Wait for ~5-30 second while new version is configured and automatically launched
  4. Enjoy!

docs.title: Important Notes
docs.text:
Library Folder

It is recommended to create a new folder on a non system drive or inside user folder like Documents to avoid any file collisions and have a nice structure.

Windows Users

Don’t use UAC protected folders like Program Files and don’t run Blender Launcher with administration rights. It may cause unexpected behavior for program itself as well as Blender 3D.

Linux Users

  • Make sure that OS GLIBC version is 2.27 or higher otherwise try to build Blender Launcher from source manually following Development documentation page.
  • Consider installing TopIcons Plus extension for proper tray icon support.

About AUR Packages

  • The AUR packages are based on this repo, but they are not maintained by core contributors of BLV2.

Blender Version Manager Users

Since Blender Launcher is written from scratch with a different concept in mind it is strongly recommended not to use a Root Folder as Library Folder. Otherwise delete all builds from Root Folder or move them to %Library Folder%\daily directory.

docs.title: Windows Time Zone
docs.text: Error Message: [ERROR]: unknown locale: en_001 Behavior: After the extraction of a build, the progress bar will be stuck at 100%. Cause: This error will appear on Windows if your Time Zone is set to English World. Workaround: Set the time zone to something else.

docs.title: Library Folder
docs.text:
Library Folder - a directory on hard drive where all downloaded builds are stored.

Warning

Don’t create Library Folder inside UAC protected folders like Program Files. It is recommended to create a new directory on a non system drive or inside user folder like Documents to avoid any file collisions and have a nice structure.

docs.title: Changing Library Folder
docs.text:
On first launch Blender Launcher will ask for choosing Library Folder. After it can be changed in Library Folder section of Settings Window.

There is known issue related to Qt and some Linux distributions like Mint where it fails to show folder browser dialog window. To pass this issue it is possible to set Library Folder via command line arguments:

Linux 
./Blender\ Launcher -set-library-folder "%PATH%"
Windows CMD 
"Blender Launcher.exe" -set-library-folder "%PATH%"

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
Library Folder has the following structure:

.
└─ %Library Folder%
    ├─ bl_symlink
    ├─ .temp
    ├─ custom
    ├─ daily
    ├─ experimental
    ├─ stable
    └─ template

docs.title: bl_symlink
docs.text: bl_symlink is a symbolic link that creates via library build context menu.

docs.title: .temp
docs.text: .temp folder is used to store downloaded *.zip and *.tar files.

docs.title: custom
docs.text:
custom folder is used to store builds downloaded by user manually (e.g. from GraphicAll). To use custom builds with Blender Launcher they must be placed inside custom folder manually:

.
└─ %Library Folder%
    └─ custom
        ├─ %custom blender build 1%
        │   ├─ ...
        │   ├─ blender.exe
        │   └─ ...
        ├─ %custom blender build 2%
        │   ├─ ...
        │   ├─ blender.exe
        │   └─ ...
        └─ ...

docs.title: daily
docs.text: daily folder is used to store daily builds.

docs.title: experimental
docs.text: experimental folder is used to store experimental branches builds.

docs.title: stable
docs.text: stable folder is used to store stable builds.

docs.title: template
docs.text:
template folder is used to store custom Blender preferences and scripts (e.g. HEAVYPOLY config). Template represents a file structure similar to one existing in Blender build (e.g. blender-2.91.0-windows64\2.91):

.
└─ %Library Folder%
    └─ template
        ├─ ...
        ├─ config
        ├─ datafiles
        ├─ scripts
        │   ├─ ...
        │   ├─ addons
        │   ├─ startup
        │   └─ ...
        └─...

More detailed information available on Blender manual Application Templates page.

docs.title: Manual Build Download
docs.text:
Note

Only standalone Blender version can be used with the Blender Launcher. Make sure to download the .zip version for Windows or the .tar.xz for Linux.

docs.title: Stable Build
docs.text:
1. Download the Stable Blender version you want to install.
  2. Extract the version.
  3. Place the extracted folder in the Stable Folder of the Blender Launcher.

docs.title: Daily Build
docs.text:
1. Download the Daily build you want to install.
  2. Extract the version.
  3. Place the extracted folder in the Daily Folder of the Blender Launcher.

docs.title: Experimental Build
docs.text:
1. Download the Branch or Patch build you want to install.
  2. Extract the version.
  3. Place the extracted folder in the Experimental Folder of the Blender Launcher.

docs.title: Custom Build
docs.text:
1. Download the Custom Blender Build you want to install (e.g., Blender For Artists).
  2. Extract the version.
  3. Place the extracted folder in the Custom Folder of the Blender Launcher.
  4. Initialize the Build in the User->Custom Library.

docs.title: Settings Window
docs.text: To open the Settings Window, use the button with a gear icon on the top left of the Main Window. All changes are saved automatically.

docs.title: Library Folder
docs.text: Library Folder - a directory on the hard drive where all downloaded builds are stored. For detailed information, check the Library Folder page.

docs.title: Launch When System Starts
docs.text:
Info

This only works on Windows.

Determines if Blender Launcher will run when the system starts.

docs.title: Show Tray Icon
docs.text: Toggles the visibility of the tray icon. If the option is disabled, Blender Launcher will shut down after closing its Main Window.

docs.title: Launch Minimized To Tray
docs.text: Determines if the Main Window will pop up when the user executes Blender Launcher, or only the tray icon will be shown.

docs.title: Worker Thread Count
docs.text: Sets the maximal number of CPU Thread Blender Launcher can use.

docs.title: Enable High DPI Scaling
docs.text: Determines if the Blender Launcher user interface will automatically scale based on the monitor’s pixel density. To apply changes, the application should be restarted.

docs.title: New Available Build
docs.text: Show OS notifications when new builds of Blender are available in the Downloads tab.

docs.title: Finished Downloading
docs.text: Show OS notifications when a build finished downloading and is added to the Library tab.

docs.title: Errors
docs.text: Show OS notification when an error occurs on the Blender Launcher.

docs.title: Default Tab
docs.text: Set which tab will be opened when Blender Launcher starts.

docs.title: Sync Library & Downloads
docs.text: Determines if the pages of Library and Downloads tabs will be automatically matched with each other.

docs.title: Default Library Page
docs.text: Sets which page of the Library tab will be opened when Blender Launcher starts.

docs.title: Default Downloads Page
docs.text: Sets which page of the Downloads tab will be opened when Blender Launcher starts.

docs.title: Use Custom TLS Certificates
docs.text: Enables the use of custom TLS certificates for secure communication with the proxy server.

docs.title: Type
docs.text: Specifies the type of proxy server to connect to (e.g., HTTP, SOCKS).

docs.title: IP
docs.text: Specifies the IP address of the proxy server and port number through which Blender Launcher will connect to the proxy server.

docs.title: Proxy User
docs.text: Specifies the username required to authenticate with the proxy server, if applicable.

docs.title: Password
docs.text: Specifies the password required to authenticate with the proxy server, if applicable.

docs.title: Check Automatically
docs.text: Automatically check if a new build has been released and send a notification if there is a new one available.

docs.title: On Startup
docs.text: If Blender launcher will check for a new build when launched.

docs.title: Min Stable Build to Scrape
docs.text: Set the minimum Blender version to scrape; this reduces the request amount and speeds up the build gathering time.

docs.title: Scrape Stable Builds
docs.text: If the Blender Launcher will gather the Stable build, disabling this will speed up the gathering of the daily build.

docs.title: Scrape Automated Builds
docs.text: If the Blender Launcher will gather the automated daily build (daily, experimental, patch).

docs.title: Downloading & Saving build
docs.text: Actions that will be performed on newly added builds to Library tab right after downloading is finished.

docs.title: Mark As Favorite
docs.text: Mark every newly added build to the Library tab as favorite depending on the branch type.

docs.title: Install Template
docs.text: Installs a template on newly added builds to the Library tab.

docs.title: Quick Launch Global SHC
docs.text: Launches builds added to quick launch via a user-defined key sequence.

docs.title: Hide Console On Startup
docs.text:
Info

This only works on Windows.

Launch Blender via blender-launcher.exe to hide the console on startup. Works on Blender version 3.0 and higher.

Known Issues

When using this feature, the number of running instances will not be shown.

docs.title: Startup Arguments
docs.text:
Adds specific instructions as if Blender were launching from the command line (after the blender executable i.e. blender [args …]).

For example, the -W (force opening Blender in fullscreen mode) argument internally will produce the following command:

%path to blender executable% -W

List of commands can be found on Blender manual Command Line Arguments page.

docs.title: Bash Arguments
docs.text:
Info

This only works on Windows.

Adds specific instructions as if Blender were launching from the command line (before the blender executable i.e. [args …] blender).

For example, env __NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD=1 __GLX_VENDOR_LIBRARY_NAME=nvidia (force Blender to use a dedicated graphics card) arguments internally will produce the following command:

env __NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD=1 __GLX_VENDOR_LIBRARY_NAME=nvidia nohup %path to blender executable% %startup arguments%
```

docs.title: First steps
docs.text:
Before creating an issue, please check the following:

  • Avoid duplicates - look through open and closed issues sections and make sure your problem is not reported by another user

  • Make sure you’re using the latest build of Blender Launcher from releases

  • If Blender 3D is closing right after running it from Blender Launcher, the problem is probably in the build itself or in configuration files

  • For general questions go to Blender Artists thread or our Discord

docs.title: Catching Application Traceback
docs.text:
• Starting from version 1.14.0 Blender Launcher ships with separate debugging releases that used to provide deeper and more user friendly way of tracing an issue:
  1. Download Blender_Launcher_v%.%.%_%_x64_DEBUG.zip for your system and reproduce the issue faced in a regular version
  2. If something goes wrong the popup window with detailed information will be shown
  3. Copy the text from the window using Ctrl+C

  • Blender Launcher logs warnings and errors into BL.log by default. To retrieve additional useful debug information use -debug flag (compatible with debugging releases):

    Windows CMD 
    .\"Blender Launcher.exe" -debug
    Linux 
    ./Blender\ Launcher -debug

  • On Linux it is possible to retrieve useful debug information using following command:

    gdb ./Blender\ Launcher
run

docs.title: How to report a bug
docs.text:
To report a bug, use an issue template. Consider attaching a BL.log file if it exists near the Blender Launcher executable.

Submit an issue

docs.title: Main Window
docs.text:
Main Window is a face of Blender Launcher where all main features can be accessed.

The top horizontal menu bar contains following buttons from left to right:

  1. Settings Menu
  2. Documentation
  3. Minimize to taskbar
  4. Minimize to tray

Main Window layout consists of three main tabs with corresponding pages:

  • Library - list of local builds ready to use
    • Stable
    • Daily
    • Experimental
  • Downloads - list of available official builds
    • Stable
    • Daily
    • Experimental
  • User - list of favorite and custom builds defined by user
    • Favorites
    • Custom

Tip

Use Scroll Wheel while hovering tabs to quickly switch between them.

Note

By default Library and Downloads pages will be automatically matched between each over. To change this behaviour toggle Sync Library & Downloads Pages checkbox in settings.

The bottom status bar shows following information from left to right:

  1. Status of application
  2. Blender Launcher version number

docs.title: Library Tab
docs.text:
Screenshots

Library Tab, Daily Page

Library tab is a place where all local builds are shown based on category. Each category contains a list of items which represents a build information. Library build item shows following information from left to right:

  1. Launch button

    Note

    Play icon on the right side of button indicates that build set to quick launch.

  2. Version number including subversion or phase (Alpha, Beta)

  3. Branch name

  4. Date and time of build commit target

    Note

    Take in mind that builder.blender.org shows when build was uploaded to server.

    Tip

    Left Button click on date and time label will show hash number and vice versa.

  5. Number of running instances / new build indicator

Tip

2x Left Button click on library build item will automatically launch build.

docs.title: Library Build Context Menu
docs.text:
Screenshots

Library Build Context Menu

Build context menu can be accessed via right click on build item.

docs.title: Open previous file
docs.text: Open the last closed file

docs.title: Add To Quick Launch
docs.text: Sets selected build to be accessed from tray icon context menu or middle click on it.

docs.title: Add To Favorites
docs.text: Add selected build to Favorites page of User tab.

docs.title: Debug
docs.text: Multiple option to investigate and debug the programe

docs.title: Register Extension [Windows only]
docs.text:
Silently register blend-file extension (show thumbnails in file explorer and use selected build as default to open *.blend files).

Known Issues

Registering may fail if *.blend files not already associated with Blender or associated with different unrelated application.

docs.title: Create Shortcut
docs.text: Create shortcut for selected build on desktop.

docs.title: Create Symlink
docs.text: Create symbolic link for selected build pointing to %Library Folder%/blender_symlink.

docs.title: Install Template
docs.text: Install template for selected build (check template for more details).

docs.title: Show Release Notes [Stable and LTS builds only]
docs.text: Reveal page with release notes for the selected build in a web browser.

docs.title: Show Folder
docs.text: Reveal the folder containing the selected build in the system file explorer.

docs.title: Edit Build
docs.text: Edit the build info used to display the installed build.

docs.title: Delete From Drive
docs.text: Delete the selected build from the drive and remove it from the Blender Launcher.

docs.title: Downloads Tab
docs.text:
Screenshots

Downloads Tab, Experimental Page

Downloads tab is a place where all available official builds are shown based on category. Each category contains a list of items which represents a build information. Downloadable build item shows following information from left to right:

  1. Download button
  2. Version number including subversion or phase (Alpha, Beta)
  3. Branch name

  4. Upload date and time of build to server

    Tip

    Left Button click on date and time label will show hash number and vice versa.

  5. New build indicator

Tip

2x Left Button click on downloadable build item will automatically start downloading.

docs.title: Download Build Context Menu
docs.text: Build context menu can be accessed via right click on build item.

docs.title: Show Release Notes [Stable and LTS builds only]
docs.text: Reveal page with release notes for selected build in web browser.

docs.title: User Tab
docs.text: User tab is a place where favorite and custom builds can be defined.

docs.title: Favorites Page
docs.text:
Screenshots

User Tab, Favorites Page

Favorites page contains builds added from Library tab using context menu Add To Favorites action. It has the same context menu as Library tab build item except possibility to rename branch title:

docs.title: Rename Branch
docs.text: Rename branch title (Enter to submit new title, Esc to reject editing).

docs.title: Custom Page
docs.text:
Screenshots

User Tab, Custom Page

Custom page contains builds that placed under custom directory of library folder. It acts the same way as the Library tab build item. After adding new builds inside the custom folder make sure to press the Reload button in the top left corner to force Blender Launcher to read it from the disk and show in the list.
